ğŸ“– Vol 1: Mysteries of Purity
And as for plucking it at the beginning of growth in imitation of beardless youths, it is among the major reprehensible acts, for the beard is the adornment of men. Indeed, Allah the Exalted has angels who distribute, and He who adorned the children of Adam with beards, and it is from the completion of creation, and through it men are distinguished from women. And it is said in an unusual interpretation: the beard is what is intended by His saying, the Exalted: 'He increases in creation what He wills' {Quran 35:1}. The companions of Al-Ahnaf ibn Qais said: 'We wish we could buy a beard for Al-Ahnaf even for twenty thousand.' And Shuraih the judge said: 'I wish I had a beard even for ten thousand.' And how can the beard be disliked when in it is the magnification of the man and looking at him with the eye of knowledge and dignity, elevation in gatherings, the turning of faces toward him, precedence over the group, and protection of honor? For whoever insults makes reference to the beard if the insulted one has a beard. And it has been said that the people of Paradise are beardless except for Harun, the brother of Musa, peace be upon them both, for he has a beard to his navel, a specification and preference for him.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
Thus, the rational person does not know what Allah has opened for His saints (awliya') and prophets from the subtleties of His gentleness (lutf) and mercy (rahma). 'What Allah opens for people of mercy, there is no withholder for it' (Quran 35:2). And this mercy is bestowed by the decree of generosity (jawd) and magnanimity (karam) from Allah, the Exalted and Glorified, not being stingily withheld from anyone. However, it only appears in the hearts (qulub) that expose themselves to the breezes (nafahat) of Allah's mercy, as the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Indeed, your Lord has in the days of your time breezes, so expose yourselves to them.' And exposing oneself to them is by purifying the heart (qalb) and cleansing it from the filth (khabath) and turbidity (kadurah) resulting from blameworthy character traits, as its explanation will come later.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
Woe to you, O Soul (Nafs)! It is not fitting that the worldly life (al-hayat al-dunya) should deceive you, nor should the deceiver (al-gharur) deceive you concerning Allah. So look to your soul (nafs), for you are not commanded with what is important for others, and do not waste your times, for the breaths are counted. When a breath passes from you, part of you has gone. So seize health before sickness, leisure before occupation, wealth before poverty, youth before old age, and life before death, and prepare for the Hereafter (al-akhira) according to the length of your stay in it, O soul (nafs). Do you not prepare for winter according to the length of its duration, gathering for it provisions, clothing, firewood, and all means, and do not rely in that on the bounty (fadl) of Allah and His generosity (karam) until He repels the cold from you without a cloak, felt, firewood, and other than that, for He is capable of that. Do you think, O soul (nafs), that the intense cold (zamharir) of Hell (Jahannam) is lighter in cold and shorter in duration than the intense cold of winter? Or do you think that that is less than this? No, it is not so, nor is there any similarity between them in severity and coldness. Do you think that the servant (al-'abd) is saved from it without striving? Far from it! Just as the cold of winter is not repelled except by a cloak, fire, and other means, so the heat of the Fire (al-nar) and its cold are not repelled except by the fortress of Oneness (Tawhid) and the trench of acts of obedience (al-ta'at). And the generosity (karam) of Allah, the Exalted, is in that He made known to you the way of fortification and facilitated its means for you, not in that He repels the punishment from you without its fortress, just as the generosity (karam) of Allah, the Exalted, in repelling the cold of winter is that He created fire and guided you to the way of extracting it from between iron and stone so that you may repel with it the cold of winter from your soul (nafs).

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
And among the wonders is that when we want wealth in the worldly life (Dunya), we sow and plant and trade and ride the seas and deserts and take risks, and when we want to seek the rank of knowledge, we understand and toil in memorizing it and repeating it and become famous, and we strive in seeking our provisions and do not trust in God's guarantee for us, nor do we sit in our houses and say: O God, provide for us. Then when our eyes covet the permanent, abiding kingdom, we content ourselves with saying with our tongues: O God, forgive us and have mercy on us. And He to whom is our hope and by whom is our honor calls to us and says: 'And there is not for man except what he strives for. And let not the deceiver deceive you concerning God. O man, what has made you arrogant toward your Lord, the Noble?' Then all of that does not awaken us nor bring us out from the valleys of our deception (Ghurur) and our hopes. So this is nothing but a tremendous trial unless God favors us with a sincere repentance (Tawbah Nasuh) by which He rescues us and grants us refuge. So we ask God the Exalted to grant us repentance, rather we ask Him to make the innermost secrets (Sara'ir) of our hearts (Qulub) yearn for repentance, and that He not make the movement of the tongue with asking for repentance the ultimate portion of our share, so that we become among those who say and do not act, and hear and do not accept. When we hear the admonition, we weep, and when the time comes for acting upon what we have heard, we disobeyâ€”a sign of abandonment greater than this. So we ask God the Exalted to bestow upon us success (Tawfiq) and right guidance (Rushd) by His grace and favor.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
The first example is the delusion (Ghurur) of the disbelievers (Kuffar), among them are those whom worldly life (Al-Hayat Al-Dunya) deluded, and among them are those whom the deluder (Al-Gharur) deluded concerning Allah. As for those whom worldly life deluded: they are those who said: 'Cash (Naqd) is better than credit (Nasi'ah), and the worldly life is cash and the Hereafter (Al-Akhirah) is credit, so it is therefore better and must be preferred.' And they said: 'Certainty (Yaqin) is better than doubt (Shakk), and the pleasures of worldly life are certain while the pleasures of the Hereafter are doubtful, so do not abandon certainty for doubt.' These are corrupt analogies resembling the analogy of Iblis when he said 'I am better than him; You created me from fire and created him from clay.' And to these is the reference in His saying, the Exalted: 'Those are the ones who have purchased the worldly life [in exchange] for the Hereafter, so the punishment will not be lightened for them, nor will they be aided.' And the cure for this delusion is either through affirmation of faith (Iman) or through proof (Burhan). As for affirmation through mere faith, it is to believe Allah, the Exalted, in His saying: 'Whatever you have will end, but what Allah has is lasting' and in His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: 'And what is with Allah is better' and His saying: 'And the Hereafter is better and more enduring' and His saying: 'And worldly life is not but the enjoyment of delusion' and His saying: 'So do not let the worldly life delude you.' And the Messenger of Allah ï·º informed groups of disbelievers of this, so they followed him, believed him, and had faith in him without demanding proof. And among them were those who said: 'I adjure you by Allah, did Allah send you as a messenger?' He would say 'Yes,' so they would believe. And this is the faith of the common people, and it removes from delusion, and this is likened to the child believing his father that attending the school is better than attending the playground, even though he does not know the reason for its being better.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
The eighth: Pride in erroneous opinion. Allah the Exalted said: "Is he whose evil deed is made fair-seeming unto him so that he sees it as good?" and He said: "And they think that they are doing well." And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) informed: that this will prevail over the latter part of this nation [101], and by this the past nations perished when they split into factions, each proud of his opinion, "and every party rejoices in what is with them." And all the people of innovation and misguidance only persist in them due to their pride in their opinions, and pride in innovation is the approval of what leads to desire and appetite with the assumption of its being truth. The treatment of this pride is more severe than the treatment of others because the possessor of erroneous opinion is ignorant of his error, and if he knew it he would abandon it, and the disease that is not known is not treated, and ignorance is a disease that is not known, so its cure is extremely difficult. Because the knower is able to clarify to the ignorant his ignorance and remove it from him, except if he is proud of his opinion and his ignorance, then he does not listen to the knower and accuses him. Indeed, Allah has imposed upon him a trial that destroys him while he thinks it a blessing, so how can his treatment be possible and how can he seek escape from what is the cause of his happiness in his belief? And his treatment in summary is that he be suspicious of his opinion always, not being deceived by it except when a decisive proof from the Book or the Sunnah or a sound rational evidence encompassing the conditions of evidences testifies, and the human will not know the evidences of the Sharia and the intellect and their conditions and the places of error in them except with a complete natural disposition and a penetrating intellect and diligence and exertion in seeking and practice with the Book and the Sunnah and sitting with the people of knowledge for a long time.

For He misleads whom He wills and guides whom He wills, and He causes death whom He wills and gives life whom He wills. But we estimate the matter proceeding according to what is customary from the established way (Sunnah) of Allah the Exalted in sending the prophets for the rectification of the religion and the worldly life. And why do I estimate this when what I estimate has already occurred? For indeed Allah sent our Prophet (peace be upon him) after an interval of messengers, and the law of Jesus (peace be upon him) had passed upon it close to six hundred years, and the people were divided into those who disbelieved in him from the Jews and idol worshippers, and into those who believed in him, and corruption had spread among them as it has spread in our time now. And the disbelievers were addressed with the branches of the law, and the wealth was in the hands of those who disbelieved in him and those who believed. As for the disbelievers, they were transacting without the law of Jesus (peace be upon him), and as for the believers, they were being lax with the foundation of belief just as Muslims are lax now, even though the era of prophethood was closer. So all the wealth, or most of it, or much of it, was unlawful (haram) (peace be upon him), and he pardoned what had passed and did not interfere with it, and he specified the possessors of hands with the wealth, and he established the law. ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
As for the verses: His statement, the Exalted, "Woe to those who pray, who are heedless of their prayer, who make show (of their deeds)" and His statement, the Mighty and Majestic, "And those who plot evil deeds, for them is a severe punishment, and the plotting of those, it will perish" said Mujahid: they are the people of ostentation (Riya'). And His statement, "We feed you only for the face (Wajh) of Allah; we desire no reward nor thanks from you" so He praised the sincere ones (Mukhlisin) by negating every desire except the face (Wajh) of Allah, and ostentation (Riya') is its opposite. And His statement, "So whoever hopes for the meeting with his Lord, let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone" was revealed after that concerning those who seek reward and praise through their acts of worship and deeds.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
The second reason: For the strength of love (Mahabbah), the strength of knowledge (Ma'rifah) of Allah the Exalted and its expansion and its domination over the heart (Qalb), and that after purifying the heart from all distractions of the world and its attachments, it proceeds like placing the seed in the earth after purifying it from weeds, which is the second half. Then from this seed is generated the tree of love and knowledge, which is the good word (Kalimah Tayyibah) that Allah struck as a parable when He said: "Allah strikes a parable of a good word like a good tree whose root is firm and its branch is in the sky." And to it is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: "To Him ascends the good word (Al-Kalim Al-Tayyib)", meaning the knowledge (Ma'rifah), "and the righteous deed (Al-'Amal Al-Salih) raises it." So the righteous deed is like beauty for this knowledge and like a servant, and indeed all righteous deeds are in purifying the heart first from the world then in maintaining its purity, so the deed is not intended except for this knowledge, and as for the knowledge of how to perform the deed, it is intended for the deed, so knowledge is the first and it is the last, and indeed the first is the knowledge of interaction (Ilm Al-Mu'amalah) and its purpose is the deed, and the purpose of interaction is the clarity (Safa') of the heart and its purity so that the clarity of the truth becomes evident in it and it becomes adorned with the knowledge of knowledge (Ilm Al-Ma'rifah), which is the knowledge of unveiling (Ilm Al-Mukashafah). And whenever this knowledge is attained, love follows it by necessity, just as one with a balanced temperament, if he sees beauty and perceives it with the apparent eye, loves it and inclines toward it, and whenever he loves it, pleasure (Ladhdhah) occurs, so pleasure follows love by necessity, and love follows knowledge by necessity, and one does not reach this knowledge after the cutting off of worldly distractions from the heart except with pure thought (Fikr Safi), constant remembrance (Dhikr Da'im), utmost effort in seeking, and continuous contemplation (Nadhar Mustamirr) in Allah the Exalted and in His attributes and in the dominion of His heavens and all His creatures.

a.g: And Allah created you from dust, then from a sperm-drop; then He made you mates. And no female conceives nor does she give birth except with His knowledge. And no aged person is granted [additional] life nor is his lifespan lessened but that it is in a register. Indeed, that for Allah is easy.

And not alike are the two bodies of water. One is fresh and sweet, palatable for drinking, and one is salty and bitter. And from each you eat tender meat and extract ornaments which you wear, and you see the ships plowing through [them] that you might seek of His bounty; and perhaps you will be grateful.

He causes the night to enter the day, and He causes the day to enter the night and has subjected the sun and the moon - each running [its course] for a specified term. That is Allah, your Lord; to Him belongs sovereignty. And those whom you invoke other than Him do not possess [as much as] the membrane of a date seed.

If you invoke them, they do not hear your supplication; and if they heard, they would not respond to you. And on the Day of Resurrection they will deny your association. And none can inform you like [one] Acquainted [with all matters].
O mankind, you are those in need of Allah, while Allah is the Free of need, the Praiseworthy.
If He wills, He can do away with you and bring forth a new creation.
And that is for Allah not difficult.

And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. And if a heavily laden soul calls [another] to [carry some of] its load, nothing of it will be carried, even if he should be a close relative. You can only warn those who fear their Lord unseen and have established prayer. And whoever purifies himself only purifies himself for [the benefit of] his soul. And to Allah is the [final] destination.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
Just as He does not hate the obedient father because of His hatred for the disobedient son, similarly He does not love the disobedient son because of His love for the obedient father. If love were to flow from the father to the son, it would be likely that hatred would also flow. Rather, the truth is that 'no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another' (Quran 35:18). And whoever thinks that he will be saved by the piety (Taqwa) of his father is like one who thinks that he will be satiated by his father's eating, quenched by his father's drinking, becomes knowledgeable by his father's learning, and reaches the Kaaba and sees it by his father's walking. Piety (Taqwa) is an individual obligation (Fard 'Ayn), so no parent can substitute for their child in it, and likewise the reverse. And with Allah is the reward of piety (Taqwa) 'on the Day when a man will flee from his brother, his mother, and his father' except by way of intercession (Shafa'a) for one upon whom Allah's anger has not intensified, so He permits intercession (Shafa'a) for him - as previously mentioned in the Book of Arrogance and Vanity.

a.g: Not equal are the blind and the seeing,
Nor are the darknesses and the light,
Nor are the shade and the heat,
And not equal are the living and the dead. Indeed, Allah causes to hear whom He wills, but you cannot make hear those in the graves.
You, [O Muhammad], are not but a warner.
Indeed, We have sent you with the truth as a bringer of good tidings and a warner. And there was no nation but that there had passed within it a warner.
And if they deny you - then already have those before them denied. Their messengers came to them with clear proofs and written ordinances and with the enlightening Scripture.
Then I seized the ones who disbelieved, and how [terrible] was My reproach.
Do you not see that Allah sends down rain from the sky, and We produce thereby fruits of varying colors? And in the mountains are tracts, white and red of varying shades and [some] extremely black.

And among people and moving creatures and grazing livestock are various colors similarly. Only those fear Allah, from among His servants, who have knowledge. Indeed, Allah is Exalted in Might and Forgiving.

And it is said: Five of the character traits are from the signs of the scholars of the Hereafter, understood from five verses from the Book of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic: Fear (Khushya), Humility (Khushu'), Humbleness (Tawadu'), Good Character (Husn al-Khuluq), and Preferring the Hereafter over the worldly life, which is Asceticism (Zuhd). As for the Fear (Khushya), it is from His saying, the Exalted: 'Indeed, only those who have knowledge (al-'Ulama') among His servants fear Allah' (Fatir: 28). And as for the Good Character (Husn al-Khuluq), it is from His saying, the Exalted: 'So by mercy from Allah, you were gentle with them' (Al 'Imran: 159). And as for the Asceticism (Zuhd), it is from His saying, the Exalted: 'But those who were given knowledge said, "Woe to you! The reward of Allah is better for he who believes and does righteous work"' (Al-Qasas: 80).

Therefore, some of the verifiers (Muhaqqiqin) said: The meaning of their saying, 'We learned knowledge for other than Allah, but knowledge refused to be except for Allah,' is that knowledge refused and withheld itself from us, so its reality (Haqiqa) was not unveiled to us; rather, we only obtained its narration (Hadith) and its expressions (Alfaz).

So observe how He, the Exalted and Majestic, began with Himself, then mentioned the angels, and thirdly mentioned the people of knowledge - and what honor, virtue, clarity, and nobility is greater than this! And Allah, the Exalted, said: 'Allah will raise those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge by degrees' (Al-Mujadilah: 11). Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: 'For the scholars are degrees above the believers by seven hundred degrees, the distance between two degrees being a journey of five hundred years.' And the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Say, "Are those who know equal to those who do not know?"' And He, the Exalted, said: 'Only those fear Allah from among His servants who are scholars' (Quran 35:28). And He, the Exalted, said: 'Say, "Sufficient is Allah as Witness between me and you, and [from] whoever has knowledge of the Scripture."' And He, the Exalted, said: 'Said one who had knowledge from the Scripture, "I will bring it to you."' indicating that he was empowered by the strength of knowledge. And the Mighty and Majestic said: 'But those who were given knowledge said, "Woe to you! The reward of Allah is better for he who believes and does righteousness."' clarifying that the greatness of the Hereafter's status is known through knowledge. And He, the Exalted, said: 'And these examples We present to the people, but none will understand them except those of knowledge.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'And if they had referred it back to the Messenger or to those of authority among them, then the ones who [can] draw correct conclusions from it would have known about it.' referring His ruling in events to their deduction and equating their rank with the rank of the prophets in uncovering Allah's ruling. And it is said regarding His saying, the Exalted: 'O children of Adam, We have bestowed upon you clothing to conceal your private parts' meaning knowledge, 'and adornment' meaning certainty (Yaqin), 'and the clothing of righteousness (Taqwa)' meaning modesty (Haya'). And the Mighty and Majestic said: 'And We had certainly brought them a Book which We detailed by knowledge.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'So We will surely relate [their deeds] to them with knowledge.' And the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Rather, it is distinct verses [preserved] within the breasts of those who have been given knowledge.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'He created manÂ¤ [and] taught him eloquence.' And He only mentioned that in the context of bestowing favor.

And the second, which is the higher, is that God is the One to be feared, meaning that the servant fears the veil from Him and hopes for closeness to Him. Dhu al-Nun, may God have mercy on him, said: 'The fear of Hell compared to the fear of separation is like a drop that has fallen into a deep sea.' And this is the fear (Khashya) of the scholars, where He, the Exalted, said: 'Indeed, only those who have knowledge (Al-'Ulama') among His servants fear God.' And the general believers also have a share of this fear, but it is merely by imitation (Taqleed), like the fear of a child from a snake by imitating his father, and that is not based on insight (Bassira), so it weakens and disappears quickly. Indeed, the child might see the snake charmer proceed to take the snake, look at him, be deceived by him, and dare to take it by imitating him, just as he refrained from taking it by imitating his father. Imitative beliefs are weak in general, unless they are strengthened by witnessing their confirming causes continuously and by persisting in their requirements in increasing acts of obedience (Taa'at) and avoiding sins (Ma'asi) for a long duration consistently. Therefore, whoever ascends to the peak of knowledge (Ma'rifa) and knows God, the Exalted, fears Him necessarily, so he does not need treatment to induce fear, just as whoever knows the lion and sees himself falling into its claws does not need treatment to induce fear into his heart (Qalb), but fears it necessarily, whether he wills or not. And for that reason, God, the Exalted, revealed to David, peace be upon him: 'Fear Me as you fear the predatory lion.' And there is no means to induce fear of the predatory lion except knowledge of the lion and knowledge of falling into its claws, so he does not need any means. Similarly, whoever knows God, the Exalted, knows that He does what He wills and does not care, and decrees what He wants, and does not fear the closeness of the angels without a prior means, and He banished Iblis.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
And as for the method of citation from the verses and reports, what has come regarding the virtue of fear is beyond enumeration, and sufficient as an indication of its virtue is that Allah the Exalted has gathered for those who fear: guidance, mercy, knowledge, and pleasure, which are the collective stations of the people of the Gardens. And Allah the Exalted said: 'And guidance and mercy for those who are in awe of their Lord' (Quran 16:128). And He the Exalted said: 'Indeed, only those who fear Allah from among His servants are the knowledgeable ones' (Quran 35:28). He described them with knowledge due to their fear. And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Allah is pleased with them and they are pleased with Him; that is for whoever fears his Lord' (Quran 98:8). And everything that indicates the virtue of knowledge indicates the virtue of fear, because fear is the fruit of knowledge. And therefore, it came in the report of Moses, upon him the best of prayers and peace: 'And as for those who fear, for them is the Highest Companion, in which they are not shared.' So see how He singled them out with the companionship of the Highest Companion, and that is because they are the knowledgeable ones, and the knowledgeable ones have a rank of companionship with the prophets, because they are the inheritors of the prophets, and the companionship of the Highest Companion is for the prophets and those who join them. And therefore (when the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was given the choice during his terminal illness between remaining in the world and coming to Allah the Exalted, he would say: 'I ask You for the Highest Companion' [60]). So then, if one looks at its producer, it is knowledge, and if one looks at its fruit, it is piety (Wara') and God-consciousness (Taqwa). And what has come regarding their virtues is not hidden, until indeed the outcome has become marked with God-consciousness (Taqwa), specified by it, just as praise has become specified for Allah the Exalted and prayer for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, until it is said: 'Praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds, and the outcome is for the God-conscious ones (Mut-taqeen), and prayers upon our master Muhammad, peace be upon him, and all his family.' And Allah the Exalted has specified God-consciousness (Taqwa) with addition to Himself, so He the Exalted said: 'Their meat will not reach Allah, nor will their blood, but what reaches Him is God-consciousness (Taqwa) from you' (Quran 22:37). And indeed, God-consciousness (Taqwa) is an expression of restraint by the dictate of fear, as preceded.

For whoever knows Allah (the Exalted) knows from His attributes that He destroys the worlds and does not care, and knows that he is subjugated in the power of One who, if He destroyed thousands upon thousands like him and made the punishment eternal upon them for eternity, it would not affect Him with any effect, nor would any compassion take Him regarding it, nor would any distress afflict Him concerning it. And therefore He (the Exalted) said: "Indeed, only those who have knowledge (al-'Ulama') among His servants fear Allah." And the opening of the Psalms: "The beginning of wisdom is the fear (Khashyah) of Allah." And Ibn Mas'ud said: "Sufficient is the fear (Khashyah) of Allah as knowledge, and sufficient is delusion with Allah as ignorance."

If you say: Why is it that some people increase in arrogance and false security with knowledge? Know that there are two reasons for this: "The first" is that he occupies himself with what is called knowledge but is not true knowledge, for true knowledge is that by which the servant knows his Lord and himself, and the danger of his affair in meeting Allah and being veiled from Him, and this produces fear (Khushya) and humility without arrogance and false security. The Fourth Duty: That he should make it public where he knows that in its publicity there is encouragement for people to follow his example, and he should guard his secret from the prompting of hypocrisy (Riya') through the method we will mention in treating hypocrisy in the Book of Hypocrisy. For Allah the Exalted has said: 'If you disclose your charitable expenditures, they are good' (Quran 2:271) {} and that is where the situation necessitates disclosure, either for emulation or because the asker only asked in public view, so one should not refrain from giving charity out of fear of hypocrisy in publicity; rather, one should give charity and guard his secret from hypocrisy as much as possible. This is because in publicity there is a third danger besides reminding of favor and hypocrisy, which is exposing the cover of the poor person, for he might be harmed by being seen in the guise of a needy person. So whoever makes the asking public is the one who exposed his own cover, so one should not be cautious of this meaning in his publicity, and it is like exposing immorality upon one who concealed it, for that is prohibited, and spying into it and habitual mention of it is forbidden. As for whoever exposes it, the establishment of the punishment upon him is publicizing, but he is the cause in it. And with a similar meaning, the Prophet ï·º said: 'Whoever casts off the garment of modesty (Haya'), then there is no backbiting for him.' And Allah the Exalted has said: 'And spend from what We have provided you, secretly and openly' (Quran 35:29) {} He encouraged to openness also because of the benefit of encouragement in it. (Description of the clothing of the people of Paradise and their furnishings, beds, couches, and tents) Allah the Exalted said: "They will be adorned therein with bracelets of gold and pearls, and their garments therein will be silk." And the verses in that are many, and its detail is in the reports. Indeed, Abu Hurairah reported that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever enters Paradise enjoys, does not despair, his clothes do not wear out, nor does his youth perish in Paradise, what no eye has seen, no ear has heard, nor has it occurred to the heart (Qalb) of a human." (And a man said: O Messenger of Allah, inform us about the clothes of the people of Paradise, are they created creation or woven weaving? The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) remained silent, and some of the people laughed. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: Why are you laughing at an ignorant one asking a knowledgeable one? Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: Rather, it splits from it the fruit of Paradise twice.) And Abu Hurairah said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Indeed, the first group to enter Paradise, their image is like the image of the moon on the night of the full moon, they do not spit in it, nor do they blow their noses, nor do they defecate, their utensils and their combs are of gold and silver, and their sweat is musk, for each one of them are two wives, the marrow of her shin is seen from behind the flesh from the beauty, there is no difference between them and no mutual hatred, their hearts (Qulub) are upon one heart (Qalb), they glorify Allah morning and evening (and in a narration) on each wife are seventy garments." And he (peace be upon him) said regarding His statement the Exalted: "They will be adorned therein with bracelets of gold": "Indeed, upon them are the crowns, the lowest pearl in it illuminates what is between the east and the west." And he (peace be upon him) said: "The tent is a hollow pearl, its length in the sky is sixty miles, in every corner of it for the believer are people he does not see."

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of the World
As if you have already reached what they have reached of affliction and solitude in the abode of the final resting place (Dar al-Mathwa), and you have been held as security in that resting place and that repository has encompassed you. How would it be for you if you witnessed the matters and the graves were overturned and what is in the chests (Sudur) was gathered, and you were made to stand for the reckoning before the Majestic King (Al-Malik al-Jalil), so the hearts (Qulub) flew out of fear from past sins, and the veils and curtains were torn away from you, and the faults and secrets appeared from you? There, every soul (Nafs) will be recompensed for what it has earned. Indeed, Allah, the Exalted and Majestic, says: "So that He may recompense those who did evil for what they did, and recompense those who did good with the best reward." And He, the Exalted, says: "And the Record will be placed, and you will see the criminals fearful of what is in it..." (the verse). May Allah make us and you among those who act according to His Book, following His allies (Awliya), until He settles us and you in the Abode of Permanence (Dar al-Maqamah) from His bounty. Indeed, He is Praiseworthy, Glorious.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
They say: 'Our Lord, take us out, we will do righteous deeds other than what we used to do.' Then Allah the Exalted answers them: 'Did We not give you life long enough for one who would remember to remember? And the warner came to you. So taste; for the wrongdoers there is no helper.' Then they say: 'Our Lord, our wretchedness overcame us, and we were a people astray. Our Lord, take us out of it; if we return, then indeed we are wrongdoers.' Allah the Exalted answers them: 'Be driven away into it and do not speak.' So they do not speak after that ever, and that is the utmost severity of punishment.

a.g: Indeed, Allah is Knower of the unseen [aspects] of the heavens and earth. Indeed, He is Knowing of that within the breasts.

It is He who has made you successors upon the earth. And whoever disbelieves - upon him will be [the consequence of] his disbelief. And the disbelief of the disbelievers does not increase them in the sight of their Lord except in hatred; and the disbelief of the disbelievers does not increase them except in loss.

Say, "Have you considered your 'partners' whom you invoke besides Allah? Show me what they have created from the earth, or have they partnership [with Him] in the heavens? Or have We given them a book so they are [standing] on evidence therefrom? [No], rather, the wrongdoers do not promise each other except delusion."
Indeed, Allah holds the heavens and the earth, lest they cease. And if they should cease, no one could hold them [in place] after Him. Indeed, He is Forbearing and Forgiving.

And they swore by Allah their strongest oaths that if a warner came to them, they would be more guided than [any] one of the [previous] nations. But when a warner came to them, it did not increase them except in aversion.

[Due to] arrogance in the land and plotting of evil; but the evil plot does not encompass except its own people. Then do they await except the way of the former peoples? But you will never find in the way of Allah any change, and you will never find in the way of Allah any alteration.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
Look at how Allah takes revenge on the envier when he desires the removal of blessing from the envied one, but He does not remove it from him; rather, He removes it from the envier. For safety from sin is a blessing, and safety from grief and sorrow is a blessing that have both been removed from him, confirming His saying, the Most High: "And the evil plot does not encompass except its own people." And perhaps he is afflicted with the very thing he desires for his enemy, and rarely does a gloating person gloat over a misfortune except that he is afflicted with its like, until Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: 'I never wished anything for Uthman except that it befell me, to the point that if I had wished him to be killed, I would have been killed.'
